alias: Reza the Skeptical Self-Learner (or Andi Irham archetype)

demographics.occupation: Professional (e.g., software engineer, grad student, or career-switcher) with full-time job or intense studies
demographics.location: Urban Indonesia, e.g., Padang (West Sumatra), Jakarta, Bandung – irregular schedule, commutes or family responsibilities
demographics.education_background: University graduate or pursuing advanced certs/exams (e.g., certification, career pivot, job interview prep)
demographics.tech_savviness: High – comfortable with apps, but burned by flashy edtech before

core_context_and_situation.daily_life: Full-time work/studies + learning squeezed into 20–60 min pockets (evenings, weekends, commutes)
core_context_and_situation.historical_experience: Tried passive tools (books, videos, courses, Anki-like apps) → felt 'familiar' but failed delayed/high-stakes tests
core_context_and_situation.triggering_events: Upcoming high-stakes moment (exam in 1–6 months, certification, job interview, career switch pressure)
core_context_and_situation.environmental_factors: Irregular schedule, noisy home/family, limited consistent time, distractions
core_context_and_situation.past_failures: Quit spaced repetition apps due to lack of trust in 'mastery' signals; overconfident from passive review → crashes on real recall

key_needs_derived_from_context: Brutal honesty: Trust that 'stable' knowledge is truly retrievable under pressure after delay (no illusion of competence)
Granular visibility: Per-concept dashboard showing stable / fragile / not-learned – hates vague global scores like '80% mastery'
Ultra-low-friction active recall: Quick type-in, voice, or cloze without multiple-choice tricks
Adaptive scheduling: Respects forgetting science but doesn't overwhelm busy life
Explanation check: Post-review prompt to catch 'I can recognize it but can't explain it in my own words'
Early warnings: Dashboard flags fragile concepts – 'Don't move on yet'
Prediction reliability: Answers 'Will I actually remember this in 30 days during the real test?'

behaviors_and_attitudes.learning_style: Goal-directed, evidence-based; prioritizes signal quality (real recall) over volume of cards
behaviors_and_attitudes.app_preferences: Avoids systems that feel like 'more homework' or gamified distractions (no badges, streaks without real signal)
behaviors_and_attitudes.frustrations: Illusion of competence from re-reading; wasted time on already-stable material; motivation drop when weaknesses hidden
behaviors_and_attitudes.values: Scientific integrity, brutal feedback, measurable retention over time, no sugarcoating

mindset_and_quote.core_mindset: I don't care about feeling good – I care about knowing what I've actually learned vs what I only think I've learned. If the app lies about stability, I'll quit.
mindset_and_quote.representative_quote: I don't want badges or streaks. I want brutal honesty about what I've actually learned versus what I think I've learned. If the dashboard predicts I'll remember something in a month and I fail, it's useless.

why_perfect_fit: Question-first flow + confidence self-report matches need for honest active recall
Concept-level tracking + stability status (stable/fragile/not-learned) directly addresses granular weakness visibility
Spaced repetition with confidence-influenced intervals prevents overconfidence illusions
Metrics like retention score, error recurrence, recall confidence ratio give the 'brutal truth' he craves
Success definition (dashboard predictions match real delayed performance) builds the trust he lost in other tools

emotional_connection_potential.in_indonesian_context: Resonates strongly in West Sumatra (Minangkabau values of deep-rooted knowledge, adat loyalty, resilience); relatable to serious learners prepping for UTBK, CPNS, professional certs, or career advancement
emotional_connection_potential.brand_tie_in: Names like Beringin (deep roots, enduring strength) or HafalTetap (true lasting mastery) would feel authentic and trustworthy to him
